results.title: Culture and recreation
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A non-narrated montage of images showing aspects of culture and recreation in Australia, interspersed with some historic footage. Shows sport, dance, historic buildings, the Sydney Opera House, opera performances and festivals. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates

results.title: Political and legal systems
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
Looks at local, state and federal governments as well as the various law courts to show how Australia has adapted the English laws of Westminster. Uses archival footage and includes segments with Malcolm Fraser and Bill Hayden.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates

results.title: Mining
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A detailed statement of Australia’s massive mining developments in the eighties - tin, coal, bauxite, iron ore as well as the production of the more rare metals such as gold, silver and uranium. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Commerce
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A look at Australia’s image within the world of commerce in the 1980’s - its transportation, stock exchanges, futures markets, and its growth in the cattle, produce and minerals industries. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Rural industries
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
Australia’s modern techniques of cultivation and harvesting are demonstrated to show how this country is a major supplier of grain to the world. The film also shows how the cattle and livestock industry supply food to most parts of the globe.

results.title: Atomic power and the U.S.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
This film examines the United States’ nuclear energy programme for the production of electric power; five types of nuclear reactors designed by U.S. Government laboratories and American industries; nuclear plants operated and financed by private industry. Atomic fuel and technical skills developed by intensive research in the United States are available to other countries through international agreement. No other credits available.

results.title: Training men for the atomic age
results.creator_credit: Hearst Metrotone and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Atoms for Peace”
The training program in nuclear physics for foreign scientists sponsored by the US Atomic Energy Commission. Shows activities at the University of Pennsylvania, Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies, International School of Nuclear Science and Engineering at La Grange, Illinois, and construction of a nuclear reactor at Shippingport, Pennsylvania.

results.title: Scientific advancement
results.creator_credit: James Blake Cahoon and Information Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes the progress made in the production of atomic electric power. Historically interesting for the 1956 prediction that atomic power will be used to eliminate poverty and war.

results.title: Agriculture, industry and power
results.creator_credit: United States Information Agency and Warner-Pathe News
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes research into the practical and beneficial uses of atomic energy and radioactive materials in agricultural and industrial production. Highlights Gama rays being used to develop better crop species, radioactive cobalt assisting fertiliser research, atomic energy detecting flaws in castings, checking wear on piston rings and, food preservation, synthetic fuel and electric power applications.
